title: Gains in Power from Structured Two-Sample Test on Means of Graphs

author: Laurent Jacob, Department of Statistics, UC Berkeley

segmentation: A simple test of differential expression and gene networks, and so it's we're dealing with a very, very classical problem of.

Doing differential expression of gene sets so you are given gene expression data for two groups of samples with two different enneatypes and well the first steps that you want to identify significant genes which have significant changes in expression between the two phenotypes.

But people are very often interested in more than that, like it was presented in before they want to do analysis at the biological function level and identify differentially expressed pathways or gene sets.
And must currently used.

Approached is a two step approach where you first Test differential expression of genes individually and then you have your your pathways and you test image Minton of gene sets in differentially expressed genes and when issue of this approach is that unit testing the right thing at exactly the thing which pathways are differentially expressed.
Your testing which pathways are enriched in differentially expressed genes and so.
For bias resented, it makes you lose some power, and it makes the results more difficult to into.
Right?
And so an alternative approach to this step method is multivariate 2 sample test.
Some people do that, so you consider that the sample to sample arise from two different multivariate normal distributions in the gene set space.
It's direct generalization of at Test that you would do for a single gene, and then you test using some material statistic.

The fact that the means of the two distributions are the same on it and few people use this approach, mostly because you lose power very quickly in high dimension because you're doing material statistics, and so if you have few samples you cannot work in high dimension and so the idea we developed is to reduce the dimension of the space in which you work using the network structure and more specifically.

If you if you have, for example, a gene regulation network for your pathway, and you expect that the difference in expression between the two, the two phenotypes is totally coherent with the network, then you can build a new subspace in which you will retain the information of a difference between the two groups.
The discretion of the two groups.
We met in much smaller dimension and so you will have more power and basically we have a.
We show that we have more power.
We have a theoretical result that we have more power in this case and we identify pathways which are more coherent which have a more coherent difference in expression.
Thank you and it's a P1.
